description: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French contenir, from Latin continēre (“to hold or keep together, comprise, contain”), combined form of con- (“together”) + teneō (“to hold”).

verbs.description: contain (third-person singular simple present contains, present participle containing, simple past and past participle contained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put constraints upon; to restrain; to confine; to keep within bounds.
examples: I'm so excited, I can hardly contain myself!

entries.meaning: (mathematics, of a set etc., transitive) To have as an element or subset.
examples: A group contains a unique inverse for each of its elements.
If that subgraph contains the vertex in question then it must be spanning.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To restrain desire; to live in continence or chastity.
examples: But if they cannot contain, let them marry.
